dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So the National Bank of Kyrgyzstan is holding the base rate steady at 17.25%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So the National Bank of Kyrgyzstan is holding the base rate steady at seventeen point two five percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The National Bank of Kazakhstan has decided to keep the base rate unchanged at 17% with a symmetric interest rate corridor of +/- 2 percentage points.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and they're keeping that symmetric corridor, um, plus or minus 1.75 percentage points, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and they're keeping that symmetric corridor, um, plus or minus one point seven five percentage points, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The National Bank of Kazakhstan has decided to keep the base rate unchanged at 17% with a symmetric interest rate corridor of +/- 2 percentage points.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And the standing facility rates are unchanged too—18.75% for liquidity provision, uh, 15.25% for withdrawal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And the standing facility rates are unchanged too-eighteen point seven five percent for liquidity provision, uh, fifteen point two five percent for withdrawal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Interest rates on standing facilities are also kept unchanged at 19% to provide liquidity and at 15% to withdraw liquidity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which makes sense given their focus on price stability and, like, financial stability risks.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which makes sense given their focus on price stability and, like, financial stability risks.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The decision on the base rate was made taking into account risks for price stability, financial stability and economic growth outlook.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But what's interesting is how they mention the economic slowdown hasn't pushed them to cut rates—they really want to keep demand for tenge assets strong.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But what's interesting is how they mention the economic slowdown hasn't pushed them to cut rates-they really want to keep demand for tenge assets strong.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Keeping the base rate at the same level in terms of economic slowdown indicates the necessity to ensure the demand for tenge assets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and it seems to be working—dollarization of deposits has actually stopped, which is a big deal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and it seems to be working-dollarization of deposits has actually stopped, which is a big deal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Situation in the domestic financial market indicates stabilization in the currency preferences of banking depositors dollarization of bank deposits has stopped.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's a sign things are stabilizing in the domestic financial market. People are starting to trust the tenge more.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's a sign things are stabilizing in the domestic financial market. People are starting to trust the tenge more.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Situation in the domestic financial market indicates stabilization in the currency preferences of banking depositors dollarization of bank deposits has stopped. The National Banks measures to increase the attractiveness of tenge instruments will continue to influence on the gradual change in population preferences in favor of national currency deposits.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Though inflation is still pretty high—15.1% year-on-year as of March 2016.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Though inflation is still pretty high-fifteen point one percent year-on-year as of March twenty sixteen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In February 2016 headline inflation reached 15.2% year-on-year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: True, but the National Bank expects it to slow down in the second half, maybe even get close to that 5-7% target range by year-end.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True, but the National Bank expects it to slow down in the second half, maybe even get close to that five-seven percent target range by year-end.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The National Bank of Kazakhstan expects that headline inflation will slow down in the second half of the year and it will approach to the upper boundary of the objective range of 6-8 percent by the end of 2016.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Fingers crossed. They've got their next decision coming up on June 2nd, so we'll see if anything changes then.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Fingers crossed. They've got their next decision coming up on June second, so we'll see if anything changes then.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The next decision of the National Bank of Kazakhstan on the base rate will be announced on May 5, 2016.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: I wonder if local businesses are ready to engage more with stakeholders instead of just, you know, raising concerns.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I wonder if local businesses are ready to engage more with stakeholders instead of just, you know, raising concerns.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Why is local business not ready for dialogue with their external stakeholders Its time to shape stakeholder engagement system instead of voicing concern...

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That part stood out to me too—like, it's time to build systems, not just complain.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That part stood out to me too-like, it's time to build systems, not just complain.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Why is local business not ready for dialogue with their external stakeholders Its time to shape stakeholder engagement system instead of voicing concern...

artist_script:
HostA: So the National Bank of Kyrgyzstan is holding the base rate steady at 17.25%.
HostB: Yeah, and they’re keeping that symmetric corridor, um, plus or minus 1.75 percentage points, right?
HostA: Exactly. And the standing facility rates are unchanged too—18.75% for liquidity provision, uh, 15.25% for withdrawal.
HostB: Which makes sense given their focus on price stability and, like, financial stability risks.
HostA: But what’s interesting is how they mention the economic slowdown hasn’t pushed them to cut rates—they really want to keep demand for tenge assets strong.
HostB: Right, and it seems to be working—dollarization of deposits has actually stopped, which is a big deal.
HostA: Yeah, that’s a sign things are stabilizing in the domestic financial market. People are starting to trust the tenge more.
HostB: Though inflation is still pretty high—15.1% year-on-year as of March 2016.
HostA: True, but the National Bank expects it to slow down in the second half, maybe even get close to that 5-7% target range by year-end.
HostB: Fingers crossed. They’ve got their next decision coming up on June 2nd, so we’ll see if anything changes then.
HostA: I wonder if local businesses are ready to engage more with stakeholders instead of just, you know, raising concerns.
HostB: That part stood out to me too—like, it’s time to build systems, not just complain.
